unnormalised: RBI Issues Guidelines on Digital Banking Unit (DBU) IDs
normalised: R-B-I Issues Guidelines on Digital Banking Unit (D-B-U) I-Ds

unnormalised: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) recently released guidelines clarifying the structure and usage of unique identifiers for Digital Banking Units (DBUs). Each DBU will be assigned a specific ID, facilitating better tracking and regulation of these digital banking outlets. The new directive aims to streamline operations and enhance transparency in the digital banking sector.
normalised: The Reserve Bank of India (R-B-I) recently released guidelines clarifying the structure and usage of unique identifiers for Digital Banking Units (D-B-Us). Each D-B-U will be assigned a specific I-D, facilitating better tracking and regulation of these digital banking outlets. The new directive aims to streamline operations and enhance transparency in the digital banking sector.

unnormalised: A key component of the guidelines is the allocation of a 7-digit alphanumeric code to each DBU. The first 3 characters will represent the bank's existing IFSC code, followed by "DBU" and then a unique 3-digit numerical sequence. For example, a DBU of State Bank of India (SBI) could have an ID like SBINDBU001. This standardized format will enable easier identification and categorization of DBUs across the country.
normalised: A key component of the guidelines is the allocation of a seven-digit alphanumeric code to each D-B-U. The first three characters will represent the bank's existing I-F-S-C code, followed by "D-B-U" and then a unique three-digit numerical sequence. For example, a D-B-U of State Bank of India (S-B-I) could have an I-D like S-B-I-N-D-B-U zero zero one. This standardized format will enable easier identification and categorization of D-B-Us across the country.

unnormalised: This move is aimed at ensuring uniformity in digital banking services. The IDs will be used for reporting purposes, customer transactions, and regulatory oversight. Customers can use these IDs to verify the authenticity of a DBU and ensure they are interacting with a legitimate banking outlet. Banks are required to display the DBU ID prominently at the physical location and on all digital platforms associated with the DBU.
normalised: This move is aimed at ensuring uniformity in digital banking services. The I-Ds will be used for reporting purposes, customer transactions, and regulatory oversight. Customers can use these I-Ds to verify the authenticity of a D-B-U and ensure they are interacting with a legitimate banking outlet. Banks are required to display the D-B-U I-D prominently at the physical location and on all digital platforms associated with the D-B-U.

unnormalised: The RBI expects all scheduled commercial banks to implement these guidelines within the next quarter. The DBU ID must be integrated into all customer-facing systems and internal reporting mechanisms. Failure to comply with these guidelines may result in penalties as per the Banking Regulation Act. The goal is to create a secure and efficient digital banking ecosystem in India, benefitting both banks and customers.
normalised: The R-B-I expects all scheduled commercial banks to implement these guidelines within the next quarter. The D-B-U I-D must be integrated into all customer-facing systems and internal reporting mechanisms. Failure to comply with these guidelines may result in penalties as per the Banking Regulation Act. The goal is to create a secure and efficient digital banking ecosystem in India, benefitting both banks and customers.

unnormalised: By assigning each DBU a distinct identifier, RBI aims to enhance security, prevent fraud, and provide a more seamless digital banking experience for citizens. The initiative aligns with the government's Digital India campaign and promotes financial inclusion by expanding access to banking services in remote areas. The reporting deadline is set for 30/06/2025.
